newsitem.title: BRAZIL: Brazil shrs end up, volume soars on options expiry.
newsitem.headline: Brazil shrs end up, volume soars on options expiry.

text.p: Brazil shares ended up 1.06 percent on soaring volume as investors settled their options Monday, brokers said.

Market turnover totalled a hefty 4.365 billion reais ($4.079 billion), the second highest volume in the exchange's history in a day of options settlement, according to the Sao Paulo bolsa's statistics.
The Bovespa index of the 48 most active stocks closed at 11,954 points, with Telebras and electrical shares leading the rise.
Traders said all Telebras options at strike prices of up to 150 reais were entirely exercised, while the 150 real options were partially exercised.
Telebras preferred, the underlying stock, closed at 151.60 reais, up 1.0 percent from Friday's close.
Brokers said the market traded lower mid-afternoon, but rebounded late in the session on short-covering.
Electrical shares continued their uptrend as investors kept moving into the power sector to take advantage of the stocks' upside potential.

Sao Paulo state power firm Cesp rose 3.47 percent to 77.20 reais.
Among other blue chips, Petrobras rose 1.99 percent at 308 reais, while private Companhia Vale do Rio Doce (CVRD) fell 0.79 percent to close at 25 reais.
The Sao Paulo bourse's power sector index, comprising the nine most liquid shares of the electrical sector, rose 0.07 percent to close at 3,274 points.
Traders said a 1.39 percent drop in Minas Gerais state higher.

Steel stocks rebounded after Friday's sharp drop caused by concerns over a probe into the sector. CSN shares closed up 2.29 percent at 35.80 reais, while Cosipa surged 7.14 percent to end at 0.60 reais.
Usiminas preferred jumped 6.8 percent to 1.10 reais.
The bolsa may open higher on Tuesday, but brokers said the day's trajectory would depend on how trade develops post-options expiry.
"It's possible some investors will sell their shares instead of holding them after the settlement," one trader said.
